comments.commentBody: So what is it you want? Slavery? Segregation? Women prevented from accessing education and jobs?

I hope he speaks out loudly and often whenever Mr. Trump does something egregious. He has more than every right to do so: he was an extraordinary president during an extraordinary time under extraordinary circumstances.

This election was contentious and saw the most contentious candidate elected. But even more important, the entire Democratic campaign was based on the fact Donald J Trump is simply mentally unfit, scholastically unprepared, and professionally unqualified for the office he is about to hold.

President Obama would be remiss if he didn't speak out. It might not change things but how could anyone knowing this departing president expect him to remain silent when his own achievements and values are so badly tarnished by a man of the caliber of Trump?
But why was he silent to Hillary's corruption and unsuitability for office?

Trump wasn't really elected. The GOP, through a systematic voter disenfranchisement and vote suppression campaign, made sure they would control 70% of the electoral college votes by 2016. They did everything in their power (gutting key provisions of the Voting Rights Act, Operation Redmap, CrossCheck, Citizens United, and more) to ensure they would gain the White House and the Senate/House majority with sights set on the ultimate plumb, the Supreme Court appointment.

@Ann: Yes.  Not to mention outside forces contributing to the whole mess.  Last night, late, comes this article about a multi-agency investigation into ties between Trump's campaign lackeys and Russia.  Apparently agents grew concerned Trump would shut it down and they wanted the public to know what was going on, That is the real scandal, and if Trump shuts it down, it's pretty good proof of his complicity.  I just somebody, somewhere keeps at it: the whiff of scandal r reminds me of Watergate, which began small and escalated quickly.

My biggest concern as a psychologist is that Mitchell and Jesse be successfully sued for every penny they earned. It is my belief that even before we changed the ethics code, their behavior clearly qualified as unethical. But maybe the code I read only pertained to clinical psychologists like me. I thought that the military psychology division was for psychologists who treated patients in the military. Now that I know what they do, I think this division should be abolished.
As to the report, we need another whistle-blower hero to leak it.

"Enhanced interrogation" was never anything more than punishment of the cruel and unusual variety. "Intelligence gathering" was the supposed rationale for this inhumane treatment, but in fact no "significant actionable" inttelligence was ever gathered. Truth be told, some Americans feel torture is appropriate punishment, whether it yields intelligence or not. The Constitution does not agree.

Until George W Bush- our first Supreme Court appointed President- the United States policy was to not torture people. It does not work, is cruel and inhuman punishment, increases the likelihood American prisoners will be tortured, yields fall evidence that sends troops and operatives on wild goose chases and undermines any moral authority we as a nation might have.

The British tortured American Soldiers in ships docked in New York during the Revolutionary War. With knowledge of that, General Washington made it policy to not torture British prisoners. Later, Tribunals the US convened executed foreign Civilians and Military Officers for waterboarding Americans as war crimes. How is it any less a war crime for our CIA to do the same?

I wonder of the values of a country where so many think Ed Snowden is a traitor, but think waterboarding is OK. I wonder of a Justice Department that has failed to punish those involved. I wonder of a President-Elect who thinks torture is OK and underlings who would gladly push the documentation down the memory hole. What kind of people have we become that our values have become so warped?

A quote widely attributed to Benjamin Franklin went like this:
“Well, Doctor, what have we got—a Republic or a Monarchy?”
“A Republic, if you can keep it.”

I'm not so sure we are keeping our Republic and we have strayed far from the ideals it was founded upon.

Not as a matter of official policy. That changed under Bush.

Torture has been against the official policy and under International Law. I served in the United States Army (1982-1990) and we were assured that any Soldier, Sailor, Airman or Marine guilty of mistreatment of any PW would be punished under the UCMJ and could also be subject to punishment under the law of Host Countries or International Law.

I would remind you that Iraq was in the International Criminal Court when Bush invaded.
I get your point on torture - and it's a good one.  But you should read a little more about Edward Snowden and what he actually disclosed if you think he wasn't a traitor.

"Until George W Bush- our first Supreme Court appointed President- the United States policy was to not torture people."
I strongly suggest that you look into the Winter Soldier Hearings.
Here is a starting point:
http://www2.iath.virginia.edu/sixties/HTML_docs/Resources/Primary/Winter...
You will see that this goes well beyond Bush.
https://emcphd.wordpress.com

We can expect this treatment to be brought upon our captured soldiers by our adversaries now until the end of the wars of man. I truly hope my children are not subjected to "enhanced interrogation techniques," (or worse tactics than outlined here in other reports) should they ever be captured serving their country. Sleep well service parents...

Barbarism breeds barbarism... Torture is wrong from the perspective of simply being human as well as the fact that US military personnel are more likely to be tortured by their opponents if they engage in it themselves.

You folks wonder why they hate us they dont hate us for our freedoms they hate us because we have destroyed their country and tortured them. It is like this for a so called Christian country they obviously dont follow the Golden Rule: Of Do Unto To Others As You Would Have Done Unto You. We ought to be sickened of how we have done this to these people.

Torture violates the Eighth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, 18 U.S.C. 2340A. Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions and UNCAT (The UN Convention Against Torture).

George W. Bush and Dick Cheney presided over the most extensive apparatus of torture implemented by any presidential administration since the birth of the American republic. They are war criminals.

Given the fact that they were at the apex of the most economically and militarily powerful country on earth, it is unlikely they will ever find themselves in the dock of the International Criminal Court at the Hague.

A possibly more productive approach for those interested in justice on this issue is outlined by Philippe Sands in his book "Torture Team": go after the six key lawyers in the Bush/Cheney administration who provided the legal rationale for Bushco's torture regime. The Bush Six are:

* David Addington, Dick Cheney's chief of staff
* Jay Bybee and John Yoo of the Department of Justice's Office of Legal Counsel
* Alberto Gonzales, attorney general
* Doug Feith, undersecretary of defense for policy
* Jim Haynes, general counsel to Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld

The documents they generated providing legal cover for torture were not free speech, they were incitements to commit crimes. May they receive the justice they so richly deserve.
He omitted John Yoo.
At a minimum, Addington, Bybee, Yoo et al. should be disbarred.
How about John Yoo and the two psychologists?

theoretically, yes, but it costs money to build new locker rooms, who's going to pay for it.  should this be the taxpayer priority for infrastructure spending or decaying roads and bridges that people die on like in Minneapolis (all people, including potentially transgender people); decaying water and sewer systems (used by all people, including potentially transgender people, who presumably want to drink clean public water); airports, trains, etc.

I said nothing about the Curiel matter. I said nothing about the government making something different for straight vs LGBT. I said that diverse groups with a variety of perspectives are more representative, and that a variety of perspectives and ideas leads to better outcomes.
If deliberate, too dishonest for the position. If inadvertent, too financially incompetent.
Yep - it should be disqualifying either way. How do you fail to disclose nearly $200,000,000 in assets and your role in offshore investment groups when you are up for TREASURY SECRETARY!?!

The government is now controlled by people who value money and power above the good of the country. They will not do their job and will delay anything getting done by a member of another political party. They will pander to their extremist base in order to stay in power. They will lie to the people, say they are for them, and once elected, kowtow to the rich who gives them the money and power. They will do anything, even if it does harm to our country and its citizens, in order to get and keep money and power. They would even ask for help from foreign dictators wishing to destroy the US in order to get that power and money. In my youth we called such people "traitors" -- today they call themselves "Republicans."

Try reading the article first. He did not fail to disclose $100mm of assets in the Caymans. The assets he failed to disclose were real estate in the US and Mexico; this is quite clearly stated in the article.

It is also very clear (reported elsewhere, but of course not here), that there was no tax evasion. What he failed to disclose re the Cayman funds were his management roles, not his ownership. And as reported elsewhere, and as he said at the hearing, his ownership of Cayman funds was included in his disclosures. Those disclosures also show he paid taxes on income from those funds.

Sad to see that more than 1,000 "critical thinkers" reflexively recommended this half-baked comment because it said what they wanted to be true, rather than what was true. I thought only those uneducated Republicans liked fake news.

Sociologists have classified lies into 3 types, starting from the weakest to the worse:
1) The unintentional lie, where the speaker does not know that what he says is not true;
2) The "white lie" where you know it is false but you do not want to hurt someone's feelings; and
3) A Republican talking point.

I only believe half of what a politician says, unless that politician is a Republican. Then I believe none of it.

How is it gratuitous?  Krugman and his intellectual and political kin are the reason we're stuck with Donald Trump.  He can't possibly not know it.  Nothing gets better till the Democrats understand that everything that is now happening is on them.  They're the ones that gave it away.  It took them nearly two generations, but they've squandered the nation's learned lessons from the Great Depression and WWII and aided and abetted the right in turning the country and world into a toxic strip mall and life into a tawdry, shallow, meaningless acquisition competition that devalues the lives of anybody outide a 100 feet radius.
so, when Hillary gave speeches at Goldman Sachs it was heralded as really bad, but now that an actual banker with interests in a tax haven will become treasury secretary, what should then one think?
A few months ago the NYT would have been publishing stories pushing the idea that her speeches proved Hillary was corrupt.  Not true but it sold newspapers.
Absolute Power Corrupts Absolutely!  This will be the Trump Administration!
Show me one of these nominees who are qualified. During Watergate thebgearings disavowing law breaking in office were run by both sides. They'd all be disgusted by this.
hold it - he is not a crook - he only appears to be one.
tut tut my good man - a mere bag of shells.
nope - just spent money on absolute necessities only - and tank the economy -

I can't decide which one of Trump's top-tier picks is the worst. Is it the treasury man who couldn't figure out how to fill out a basic financial form? Is it the education choice who sneers at public schools? The would-be labor secretary who doesn't believe in giving workers breaks? The state department nominee who doesn't know the difference between foreign diplomacy and foreign business deals?
Is it stupidity, ignorance or good old ego that makes the choices for attorney general, energy secretary, and health and human services head think it's OK to take a job when they don't actually believe in its key functions?
What will be left after the whole crew dismantles their own departments?
Why it's time to return to making millions, billions or bad hamburgers.

And then there is the complete idiot ex governor of Texas that couldn't remember the name of the department he was appointed to lead. He could not remember it when he was trying to tell the American people that he thought the Department of Energy should be eliminated. Pure swamp gas.
The world is scourged by narcissists whose rage has been stimulated by charlatans like Donald Trump.
Sure, these guys chat about quantum chromodynamics over tea and crumpets.
